RPKI Manifest Number Handling RPKI Manifest Number Handling
draft-ietf-sidrops-manifest-numbers-02 draft-ietf-sidrops-manifest-numbers-03
Abstract Abstract
The Resource Public Key Infrastructure (RPKI) makes use of signed The Resource Public Key Infrastructure (RPKI) makes use of signed
objects called manifests. A manifest lists each file that a objects called manifests. A manifest lists each file that a
publisher intends to include within an RPKI repository, and can be publisher intends to include within an RPKI repository, and can be
used to detect certain forms of attack against a repository. used to detect certain forms of attack against a repository.
Manifests include a "manifest number" (manifestNumber), which the Manifests include a "manifest number" (manifestNumber), which the
publisher must increment whenever it issues a new manifest, and publisher must increment whenever it issues a new manifest, and
Relying Parties (RPs) are required to verify that a newly-retrieved Relying Parties (RPs) are required to verify that a newly-retrieved

For a subordinate CA, the risk of repository invalidation due to this For a subordinate CA, the risk of repository invalidation due to this
problem can be addressed by the publisher simply using the key problem can be addressed by the publisher simply using the key
rollover process ([RFC6489]) to get a new CA certificate. RPs will rollover process ([RFC6489]) to get a new CA certificate. RPs will
treat this new certificate as though it represents a distinct CA, and treat this new certificate as though it represents a distinct CA, and
the manifestNumber can be reset at that point. the manifestNumber can be reset at that point.
However, this option is not available for RPKI Trust Anchors (TAs). However, this option is not available for RPKI Trust Anchors (TAs).
If a TA publishes a manifest with the largest-possible manifestNumber If a TA publishes a manifest with the largest-possible manifestNumber
value, then it is not possible to make use of the TA after that value, then it is difficult to rely on the TA after that point, since
point, because the certificate location (stored in the associated (per earlier comments) some RPs will not accept a new manifest until

changed. Issuing a new TA and distributing the associated TAL to manifests indefinitely. Particularly in the case of TAs, the
clients would involve a large amount of work for TA operators and manifest validity period may be quite long, too. Issuing a new TA
RPs, and there would be a limited degree of RPKI protection by way of and distributing the associated TAL to clients would involve a large
that TA for the time between the issuance of the problematic manifest amount of work for TA operators and RPs. Additionally, depending on
and the installation of the new TAL for a given client. the RP implementation in use by a client, there would be a limited
degree of RPKI protection by way of that TA for the time between the
issuance of the problematic manifest and the installation of the new
TAL.

publishers and RPs can handle this scenario in order to facilitate publishers and RPs can handle this scenario in order to facilitate

Appendix A. Serial Number Arithmetic Appendix A. Serial Number Arithmetic
Serial number arithmetic [RFC1982] is an approach that has been used Serial number arithmetic [RFC1982] is an approach that has been used
in the DNS context (among others) to permit the indefinite use of a in the DNS context (among others) to permit the indefinite use of a
finite number space. At least in theory, it would be possible to use finite number space. At least in theory, it would be possible to use
a similar approach with the manifestNumber field as well. a similar approach with the manifestNumber field as well.
